courses.name: Introduction to Women and Gender Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An integrated and historical approach to social relations of gender, race, class, sexuality and disability, particularly as they relate to womens lives and struggles across different locales, including Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Women and Gender Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

All lectures in this course will be delivered synchronously online and recorded for later viewing. Tutorials will begin online and, conditions permitting, switch to dual delivery at the instructor’s and TA’s discretion. 

Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule with recordings available afterward for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous and (if applicable) in person at their scheduled times. (Tutorials will begin entirely online, with in-person sections beginning only at the instructor's discretion.) It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines modes of theories that shaped feminist thought and situates them historically and transnationally so as to emphasize the social conditions and conflicts in which ideas and politics arise, change and circulate.
cmCourseInfo.title: Texts, Theories, Histories (formerly WGS262H1/WGS262Y1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

WGS260H1F is an online class that uses both synchronous and asynchronous paths of learning. There will be live tutorials and all-class meetings where we have opportunities to come together for discussion, lectures, live reading, and other forms of gathering. We will be using Zoom, Quercus, google docs, and Piazza. The class will be designed with accessibility as a core value.

cmCourseInfo.description: A critical examination of institutions, representations and practices associated with contemporary popular culture, mass-produced, local and alternative.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender in Popular Culture

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will include optional synchronous meetings with the instructor and TAs, but can also be completed asynchronously. 

Delivery Instructions

This course is an online asynchronous course with optional synchronous elements. Course content, including prerecorded mini lectures, will be published weekly and available for asynchronous viewing. Students will be expected to cover this content prior to class meetings. Optional weekly synchronous activities — live discussions, workshops, and drop-ins with the instructor and TAs — will be scheduled on Thursdays. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Using a transnational, feminist framework, this course examines material and conceptual interrelations between gendered human and non-human nature, ecological crises, political economies and environmental movements in a variety of geographical, historical and cultural contexts. Does environmental justice include social justice, or are they in conflict? What might environmental justice and activism involve?
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender & Environmental (In)Justice

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will begin entirely online and switch to dual delivery at the instructor’s discretion. 

Delivery Instructions

This course will begin entirely online and switch to dual delivery ONLY at the instructor’s discretion. Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule until the shift to dual delivery (if applicable). Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines how masculinities shape the lives of men, women, transgender people. Effects of construction, reproduction and impact of masculinities on institutions such as education, work, religion, sports, family, medicine, military and the media are explored. Provides critical analysis of how masculinities shape individual lives, groups, organizations and social movements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Men and Masculinities

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Women and Revolution in the Middle East

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the conplex and conflictual relations between women and revolutionary struggles and foces on a number of theoretical and empirical issues relevant to the Middle East and North Africa context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Women and Revolution in the Middle East
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS335H1 Women and Revolution in the Middle East

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

courses.name: Making Knowledge in a World that Matters

cmCourseInfo.description: Teaches skills in feminist approaches to making knowledge. Introduces feminist practices for doing research and navigating the politics of production and exchange. Develops skills for conveying knowledge to the wider world, such as through research papers, reports, performance, new media, art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Making Knowledge in a World that Matters

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the operation of the law as it affects women, the construction and representation of women within the legal system, and the scope for feminist and intersectional analyses of law. Includes an analysis of specific legal issues such as sexuality and reproduction, equality, employment, violence and immigration.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender Issues in the Law

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures may also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: The Politics of Gender and Health

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines diverse traditions and normative models of health (e.g. biomedicine, social constructionist, indigenous health) in conjunction with analyses of the origin, politics, and theoretical perspectives of contemporary Womens Health Movements. Topics may include fertility, sexuality, poverty, violence, labour, ageing, (dis)ability, and health care provision.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Politics of Gender and Health

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.  Tutorials will be conducted online synchronously.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines gendered representations of race, ethnicity, class, sexuality and disability in a variety of colonial, neo-colonial, and post-colonial contexts. Topics may include the emergence of racialist, feminist, liberatory and neoconservative discourses as inscribed in literary texts, historical documents, cultural artifacts and mass media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Post-Colonialism

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Drawing on diversely situated case-studies, this course focuses on the ideals that inform struggles for social justice, and the mechanisms activists have employed to produce the change. Foci include the gendered implications of movement participation, local and transnational coalition, alternative community formation, and encounters with the state and inter/supra/transnational organizations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Utopian Visions, Activist Realities

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

This course will begin entirely online and switch to dual delivery at the instructor’s discretion. 

Delivery Instructions

This course will begin entirely online and ONLY switch to dual delivery at the instructor’s discretion. Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary study of gendered violence in both historical and contemporary contexts including topics such as textual and visual representations; legal and theoretical analyses; structural violence; war and militarization; sexual violence; and resistance and community mobilization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Violence

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Students will need BbCollaborate; access to the course website (Quercus) and the ability to use learning platforms and software made available by the university, including Office 365 (including PowerPoint), Piazza (for discussion), Bb Collaborate, and access to a Google account for collaborative work via Google documents and slides. Students require access to a webcam and microphone.

cmCourseInfo.description: Sexual agency as understood and enacted by women in diverse cultural and historical contexts. An exploration of the ways in which women have theorized and experienced sexual expectations, practices and identities. This course will be offered every three years.
cmCourseInfo.title: Feminist Studies in Sexuality

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Studies in Queer and Trans (formerly WGS272H1/WGS272Y1)

cmCourseInfo.description: Takes up conversations in queer and trans studies as separate and entangled fields. It explores how queer and trans people have experienced and theorized gender and sexuality.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Queer and Trans (formerly WGS272H1/WGS272Y1)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: Comics aren't new, and graphic novels aren't either, but feminists have built a rich array of stories about consciousness, resistance, and coming of age in this genre that warrant scholarly attention. In this case, we will read graphic novels for their subtleties, thinking about what picture and text make possible in the exploration of emotion, interconnection, and identity. Reading about resistance to marriage in Ay of Yop City, a child's view of revolution in Perspolis, parent child reckoning in Fun Home, and loneliness in Skim will advance students' understandings of the of the power of narrative and the pictorial displacement of innocence.
cmCourseInfo.title: Feminist Graphic Novels

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Students may also be asked to subscribe to the learning platform Top Hat.

cmCourseInfo.description: Reviews major feminist transnational, Marxist and Foucaultian approaches to the study of neoliberalism. Adopts a comparative, historical and global approach to the ways that gender is implicated in state restructuring, changing roles for corporations and non-governmental organizations, changing norms for personhood, sovereignty and citizenship, and changing ideas about time/space.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gender and Neoliberalism

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

courses.name: Land-ing: Indigenous and Black Futurist Spaces

cmCourseInfo.description: Students are invited to think through the relationships between Indigenous and Afro-futurist concepts of land. This class will engage Indigenous feminist and Black queer and feminist theories of land and space, linking them to Afrofuturist and Indigenous futurist thought. We explore various texts in relation to emergent methodologies, decolonial desires, and love and radical relationalities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Land-ing: Indigenous and Black Futurist Spaces
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS335H1 (Special Topic in Women and Gender Studies: Indigenous Feminist Theory), offered in Fall 2015, WGS335H1 (Special Topic in Women and Gender Studies: Decolonial Aesthetics and Futurities), offered in Winter 2018, Winter 2019 and Winter 2020

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the ways in which bodies are lived and enscribed and represented through a variety of genres. Students will work through issues of corporeality and materiality in the production and reception of texts and will practice embodied writing on a personal level through in-class workshops and written assignments.
cmCourseInfo.title: Writing the Body

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule. Recordings of lectures will likely be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Women and Gender Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level seminar. Topics vary from year to year depending on instructor. Please consult the Women & Gender Studies Institute's website for more information.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Women and Gender Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1, one full course at THE 300+ level in WGS, and one half course in WGS.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Women and Gender Studies

cmCourseInfo.description: An upper level seminar. Topics vary from year to year depending on instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Topics in Women and Gender Studies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1, one full course at THE 300+ level in WGS, and one half course in WGS.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the ways environmental violence is an integral practice of settler colonialism that affects human and non-human life, disrupts Indigenous sovereignty, and enacts ongoing racism. A typical way of addressing environmental violence is to document the harm done to bodies and communities. This class asks, how might we also refuse environmental violence and enact better obligations to land/body relations? What kind of decolonial futures can be summoned in the aftermath of environmental violence? Our readings will bring Indigenous feminist approaches together with Black feminist, queer, and feminist environmental justice approaches. Participants will build upon the readings to create their own decolonial environmental justice future projects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Toxic Worlds, Decolonial Futures
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1, one full course at the 300+ level in WGS, and one half course in WGS.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS463H1 (Advanced Topics in Gender Theory: Toxic Worlds, Decolonial Futures), offered in Winter 2018, Winter 2019 and Winter 2020

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

courses.name: Independent Study in Women and Gender Studies Issues

cmCourseInfo.description: Under supervision, students pursue topics in Women and Gender Studies not currently part of the curriculum. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Study in Women and Gender Studies Issues
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of the Undergraduate Coordinator, Women and Gender Studies Program.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For WGS451H1 F Independent Studies (E enrolment indicator) students should fill out the application form available at https://wgsi.utoronto.ca/undergraduate/courses/#400. If you have questions, please contact the WGS Program Office at wgsi.programs@utoronto.ca. 

Delivery Instructions

The delivery of independent studies is unique to each project. The projects might involve dual delivery (with a combination of in-person and online components) or might be fully online (with a combination of synchronous and asynchronous components). In-person research will only proceed if it is safe and practical to do so, in accordance with university directives. Weekly contact hours will vary depending on the project and will be determined in consultation with the faculty supervisor.

cmCourseInfo.description: Supervised undergraduate thesis project undertaken in the final year of study. Students attend a bi-weekly seminar to discuss research strategies, analytics, methods and findings. A required course for Specialist students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Honours Seminar
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1, one full course at the 300+ level in WGS, and one half course in WGS.

cmCourseInfo.description: The application of theoretical study to practical community experience. Advanced Women and Gender Studies students have the opportunity to apply knowledge acquired in the Women and Gender Studies curriculum through a practicum placement within a community organization. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1, one full course at the 300+ level in WGS, and one half course in WGS.

courses.name: Translating Sexuality: Queer Migration, Queer Diasporas

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how notions of sexuality travel as people move within and beyond national borders. It investigates how queer and trans migrants pursue different versions of belonging, solidarity, survival, and hope. Participants will study transnational archives (which may include popular culture, new media, film, literature, and performance) as they trace globalization's effects on racialized, queer, and trans communities. Major topics may include: queer of color critique; queer settler colonialism; transnational and global south sexualities; imperialism and militarism; neoliberalism and homonationalism; humanitarianism and sexual rights; queer and trans social movements; postcolonial intimacies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Translating Sexuality: Queer Migration, Queer Diasporas
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: WGS160Y1, one full course at the 300+ level in WGS, and one half course in WGS
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: WGS434H1 (Topics: Trans/national Sexuality), offered in Fall 2016 and Fall 2017

notes.name: Course Note
